instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi guys I have a Retina 3476 that had a tiny liquid spil on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, see attached images. Rest of board looks good.

- 12.65v coming in at pin 23 VIN
- 3.43v at pin 21 <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>
- 3.43 at pin 12 <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
- 0v at <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> Pin 4

Seems I need to troubleshoot the <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> signal which I did:

- <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> = 0 ohm and 0v
- <RESISTOR>R8175</RESISTOR> = 0 ohm

- <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> = 100ohm
- <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> = 3.34v on pin 5 ov on Pin 1
- <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR> = 0 ohm
- <RESISTOR>R8184</RESISTOR> = 330ohm
- <RESISTOR>R8186</RESISTOR> = 36.6k (schematics says 39K, checked another board its 37K should be OK?)
- <RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR> = 0 ohm
- <RESISTOR>R8183</RESISTOR> = 325 ohm
- <RESISTOR>R8188</RESISTOR> = 58k ohm (schematics says 68k, another board I have is also 58 so seems OK)

Any suggestions what to look for? Whats should <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> show for voltage? Any suggestions welcome:D.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: UPDATE: got a spinning fan but not starting up, no chime. Tried PRAM to no avail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: CPU Vcore present? USB mouse lighting up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 8642"]CPU Vcore present? USB mouse lighting up?[/QUOTE]

OK will check tomorrow. I have an idea the CPU is the issue as soon as I turn the Mac on, the fan spins and cpu gets very hot. The fan will turn off and then on again etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: If the fan is on/off it is power cycling. Also check for corrosion around BIOS chip/clock chip and diagnostic connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: There is as good as no corrosion it was just a tiny spot in one place,  checked all board with microscope. Tomorrow I will check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: No light on Mouse and no vcore present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: OK so now the fan stopped spining and im back to no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> ^^ ...great:)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: Did you clean around the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>? Just ultrasonic the whole board and inspect those traces at the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: Yes the board was already very clean it was just one drop in some leg of <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>, we replaced it. 3.3v coming out just no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. Well, I did get a spinning fan before. I try clean again. Do these boards power on automatically when charger is plugged in?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message:
Update: cleaned it all again, assembled together now it again starts spinning, 2-3 times then it stops. I measured CPU Vcore it was 1.74v at <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> oin 1 and then drops to 0 and fan stops spinning.

Another update, now i kept it on the charger for a longer time with battery connected. The fan starts spinning max and does not switch of anymore. CPU VCore is at 1.739v. The USB can power an external drive, but mouse doesnt light up.

Edit: could it be current sensing issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: Check the resistors in the SPI ROM data lines and check around clock chip

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6103</RESISTOR> = 81k and on another board I have 99K according to schematics, to much difference so replace?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: No, you are measuring in circuit so 81K is fine. It is the low value ones 15 and 45 ohm I think that always corrode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina liquid damage
threads.message: the board has 0 sigh of corrosion though. I checked them all the rest is OK, on to the clock chip now
